docs.lead_paragraph: In the United States Senate, where the minority theoretically enjoys a right to unlimited debate (a k a, the filibuster), time is arguably the most fearsome weapon in the parliamentary arsenal.

headline.main: G.O.P. Senators in Rush to Delay Health Bill

docs.abstract: Even as Senate Republicans aim to kill the health bill, they accuse the Democrats of proceeding too slowly.

docs.lead_paragraph: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

docs.lead_paragraph: By expanding Medicare and keeping a government insurance plan only as a backup, Democrats hope to offer something to both liberals and centrists.

headline.main: Public Option Keeps Toehold in Senate Deal on Health Bill

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate calendar is packed. Between major health care legislation and a long list of other crucial business, lawmakers have been working almost nonstop. And Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, said Wednesday that he and his wife had given up on making it back home for Christmas. The bright side for him, Mr. Leahy said, is that he is encouraged by the latest developments on the health care bill, including a tentative deal on the so-called public option.

headline.main: It's All Work and No Play

docs.abstract: Sen Patrick J Leahy and his wife say they have given up on returning home for Christmas because of Senate's packed schedule, notably its work on major health care legislation (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dana P. Goldman, a professor of medicine and public policy at the University of Southern California, posted at the Economix blog: Why can't Congress write a heath care bill that saves money?
docs.abstract: Dana P Goldman, professor of medicine and public policy at University of Southern California, posts message on Economix blog discussing reasons for lawmakers' inability to write health care bill that saves money; says key problem is unwillingness to come to grips with need to limit access to some treatments (M)
docs.snippet: Dana P. Goldman, a professor of medicine and public policy at the University of Southern California, posted  at the Economix blog:     Why can't Congress write a heath care bill that saves money?
